comments.commentBody:
I thought that in 2007 and in 2010, every single agency involved in American security declared that Iran abandoned it's nuclear program in 2003. And, as reported in the NYT, the next report, due out this year, concludes the same thing.

So, why is this even a conversation?

Is it because we now know that Ahmed Chalibi was an Iranian agent who helped stoke the Bush administration into starting a war in Iraq, which Iran apparently has won?

THANK YOU SALADINA

I am about to go mad at the drivel being posted here. What do people think that doctors do for eight long years in medial school anyway?

I would add that the Cochrane Review is NOT connected to “BigPharma” in any way and is the GOLD STANDARD of medical review.

There are certainly problems with BigPharma, but good doctor’s know how to read and interpret studies. They make their recommendations based on the PREPONDERENCE OF THE EVIDENCE, that is: long term, high quality, independent studies of large populations.

It's good to remember too, that there are right wing crazies in Israel for the pols there to court, just like here. His crazies ignore agreed to bans on West Bank expansion and like to treat their women in the Santorum way, and like our Tea Party they are very loud, bombastic, and living in the past.

And just like here, what Netanyahu says in a speech to potential donors can be different than what he means 'for real'.

Bottom line (and remember, I have about the same amount of foreign policy experience as Liz Cheney), Israel needs the US to take the hit for any attack in Iran, because they are not able to take it themselves.

Just look at the board.

Something is seriously wrong with AIPAC just as there is something seriously amiss with Netanyahu and Israel's Likhud Party if they have to depend on American politicians as morally, ethically and politically challenged as Liz Cheney and Dick, her arrogant, failed ex-vice president of a father.

Beware anyone who says that sanctions are not aimed at the Iranian people. I heard the same lies when sanctions were being placed on the Iraqi people. (According to the 2002 UNICEF report, those sanctions on Iraq resulted in several hundred thousand children dying as a direct result of sanctions.) So please.... don't try to tell us that these sanctions on Iran are not directed at the Iranian people. It has already been reported that Iranian children are dying from cancer because of lack of treatment due to these sanctions. (The "duel use" issue always raises it's ugly head.... and our leaders are well aware of it's devastation)
Follow international law. That is the only way to solve this problem.
Are we really that stupid to go to war all over again?
Elect leaders who don't think that a carrot and stick approach to world peace will work. Elect one that believes in international law.
Iran has every right to nuclear power for civilian needs. It has the right to process it's own fuel.
The UN ...controlled by a minority of the most powerful........ thinks it can ignore Iran's rights.

It could become true - if you saddle your horse from the back:
the US leave others alone and mind their own business.

I have a dream, that one day Israel will sign the NPT, declare no-first-use, give back those illegal settlements to Palestinians. Iran will let go all its nuclear bomb ambitions, and welcome IAEA with open arms. Israel, Iran, Palestine and others all shake hands, swear friendship, coexistence, and peace. And then we, the US, can be left alone, to mind our own businesses.

I know. It's a dream.

@ jeka n.y.

You may like it or not, but Iran is a sovereign country, which gives them the right to anything any other country does. Iran was for a long time no more than a plaything of the West, with governments being overthrown and replaced at whim. Maybe they just had enough of being bullied around?

Plus, Iran signed the NPC, which is a lot more than Israel did.Speaking of which, Israel in all probability has the bomb, but of course nobody knows for sure. Why don't they let inspectors into their country? Many will say, why should they? Which brings us right back to the top.

Do you remember Iraq's WMDs?
Are US facilities open to inspection?
And who proliferated happily to Israel. Pakistan (and then: North Korea)?
So, who gives a damn about treaties?
And then tries to blackmail others with unproven accusations?
Would you let Chinese (i.e. potential enemies) check all your scientific facilities - and everything else, which gives them the opportunity to scout out every bombing target, as in Iraq and Libya?
Would you trust someone whose proxy war attack, using Saddam's Iraq, cost you overr 250,000 lives.
Would you trust someone who managed a putsch against your elected government (Mossadegh in 1953) and established a terror monarchy to lasst with their weapons and support for 26 years?
The Iranians have good reason to distrust the US.

The question is rhetorical if and only if you accept that the only reason for a nation to refuse inspection is that they are hiding something.

Let me suggest a few other options:

The Iranians might be distrustful of inspections, given that the inspection of Iraq's facilities led to the determination that they were harboring WMDs, providing justification for war. Ever consider that historical possibility?

The Iranians might not recognize the right of the international community to inspect them, given the conditions.

The Iranians might reject the grounds under which the inspections would take place.

The Iranians might object to the manner in which the inspections would take place.

The Iranians might object to certain facilities being on the list for inspection because they know for a fact they are not involved in nuclear arms production, yet they do not want them inspected for other national security reasons.

The Iranians might object to certain individuals on the inspection team because of past statements or actions.

It is just possible that the Iranians are NOT producing nuclear weapons, but are convinced, based on the rhetoric and past actions of countries like Israel, that no matter what they do they will be viewed as having them. It would not be unreasonable for Iran to presume that Israel and the US would countenance bombing Iran based on simple conjecture and assumptions, which is exactly the message being sent right now.

The iranian leaders said repeatedly that they are not developing an atomic weapon.  So, Iran refuses the inspectors to get into some secret facilities.  What is the other reason, except hiding there a nuclear weapon development site So, Iran refuses the inspectors to get into some secret facilities.  would it be?  What are they hiding in there, that they don't want anyone to see?  The question is rather a rhetorical one, isn't it?

I'd like to see Walter McGill from McDonald, TN up on a ladder doing some carpentry. Shoot, I'd like to see ole Walter up out of his chair. Shoot, I'd like to see Walter's ladder. Walther, you need to quit eaten' them grits and hog jowls and send some of the leftovers to the Sudan, ole Son.

Even a majority of Israeli`s aren`t "Netanyahu". His status as lead Zionist persuctor and ethnic cleanser of Palestinians is based on a cobbled coalition with ultra religious zealots.

Zionism is the problem as defined by the actions and policies of the leadership of Israel aginst the indigenous population of Palestine for the last 70 years.

Yonkers, New York
06 March 2012

Just when Iran's leaders were pretty close to being convinced that Israel was ready to take out its nuclear facilities unilaterally and preemptively, all of a sudden they are agreeing to more talks!

They knew why Israeli Prime MinisterBenyamin Netanyahu had to go to Washington to meet with President Barack Obama: it was to get the U.S. to agree to Israel's decisiion, an Existentialist one, to take out Iran's nuclear facilities--and now that Iran may not yet have those nuclear weapons..

But in the recent press conference which Both Mr. Obama and Mr. Netanyahu gave, Mr. Obama made it clear that the U.S. was not in favor of going to war against Iran; he is for more sanctions. And he agrees to more talks with Iran's leaders yet once again.

But it was obvious that Mr. Netanyahu has other ideas. Cryptically, facing Mr. Obama, he said: "We are you, and you are us!"

What he meant is anybody's guess.

Mariano Patalinjug

James:

Two good thoughts. Appreciate the note.

The goodwill factor does get overlooked sometimes, I think because it's less quantifiable. But as someone who has traveled and lived abroad for a good number of years, I can attest (at least anecdotally) that American goodwill still very much exists. For all the angry protests over Koran burnings, the detentions of aid workers and the occasional attacks on McDonald's and KFC franchises, the United States is widely admired. This is purely my personal impression after having traveled to 102 countries.

One quick example: I lived in Hanoi, Vietnam, for four years and traveled the country top to bottom. Even in areas that were devastated during the war I never encountered a single episode of hatred or animosity. Quite the opposite: I was welcomed with an astounding level of goodwill and hospitality, whether in gleaming offices, cement-block houses or bamboo shacks. The Vietnamese, even former Viet Cong fighters and people who were deeply affected by the war, notably from Agent Orange, have moved on. I never heard a harsh word or had an uneasy moment.

Sorry for the digression, but it's my personal belief that a little goodwill and a certain amount of soft power still go a long way overseas. Sacks of wheat in a drought in Chad, cans of cooking oil in Armenia, deliveries of cement in post-tsunami Aceh, pup tents and jugs of clean water after a hurricane in Burma --- despite America's current economic challenges, we can still well afford this stuff. In fact, I would make the case we can't afford NOT to keep providing this kind of help. OK, apologies for the mini-rant.

Again, I appreciate your (and everyone's) comments.

Mark

So Romney wins Ohio by a few thousand votes. My question is, does that still make him the one strong leader, sorry, I mean the most electable candidate of the Republican Party. I mean he takes 38% of the vote in a state he must carry in November. Does that make him a legitimate front runner?

That's dolce far niente for me.

This study has nothing to do with cholesterol. It is an investigational study of resverirol (found in red wine), which shows potential for being a factor in protecting against heart disease. But beware, if you exceed modest amounts (5 oz/day for women), you increase risks as well as risk for some cancers, and any amount of alcohol increases (somewhat) the risk of breast cancer.

Actually right after the election it did go down. Of course you are correct several months earlier it was at a record high.  Errors of omission by Mr Gingrich, half truths. Small details that we don't need to worry our pretty little heads about.

I have a great idea, to help change the status quo, lets elect an old money politician from Massachusetts, who basically swings wherever the political winds blow. Lets make sure first he looks like the type of President we would want and sounds like one too. Wait I forgot what we are in, 2004 or 2012? and if I squint hard enough I think i see some Heinz money mixed with that Romney money. Its
time that those of us who believe in building a better America stop running to the same flaccid leadership. Fiscal responsibility can go hand in hand with social conciseness. Effective social initiatives will only be feasible with true fiscal responsibility. Its time the houses of Milton Friedman and John Maynard Keynes come together. Let me finish by saying Mr. Romney, you're no Ronald Reagan.

I can not help but look at the demographics of the voters that are profiled in the NYT blog and wonder if the Republican party is in for a long term decline. The ages (80's - 1 person, 70's - 2 people, 60's - 5 people, 50's - 2 people, 40's - three people, 30's - 1 person), no obvious ethnic minorities, etc. There was also 29 YO person who supported Obama.

Perhaps if we all pray, outlaw gay marriage, prohibit contraception, etc. many of these people would be happy but it would fix the real problems in this country.

A scary thought.
@godizilladkkdjifadl-  Please watch Stephen Colbert discussing Mitt Romney's Rally at Ford Field of 2/24/12.   65,000 Plastic seats.

Well argued Chaz,

Bottom line, no one benefits from a preemptive attach. In fact the nation pulling the trigger first will pay for generations. Time for everyone to grow up. The idea that Iran wants to take on the roll of suicide bomber is just incredibly wrong.

Only about 38 per cent of the GOP voters picked Romney.
Get this , 62 percent voted for a triad of wackos , who have NO chance of beating Obama.
GOP is a party looking backwards.
The future , as the President of Israel Shimon Peres said tonite , is the time for new technology , cultural diversity , intellectual curiosity , peace and friendship.
Currently , the GOP is a dinosaur.

Apparently the Republicans have sent out a memo that a long, drawn-out, negative primary season will only make the final candidate stronger, and that it is good.
They just live in their own world and parallel universe where up is down and we are all Through the Looking Glass.
Good luck guys.

Is it just me or does anyone else think that Mitt resembles those Easter Island stone heads.

Mark:

You connect a lot of political dots in your comment. Being too much of a snark myself sometimes, I appreciate the slide into sarcasm. I am imagining the kind of Orwellian bureaucracy that would result in a U.S. Treasury check eventually being mailed off to a third cousin of Kim Jong-un. You made my morning.

Cheers, Mark

Funny you got through medical school at all.

Who ever said statins are a “magic bullet”?

Healthy skin is largely the result of genetics and basic hygiene, not any special food outside of a balanced diet. Perhaps you should take up your practice in the “East”--you know, where real doctors also practice “Western” medicine.
Yup. Skinflints...
Lots of us care, John;  don't be sad.
Leapy, you funny punster, you replied to me yesterday with another who cares but nobody cared.

Maureen:

You point out a very important angle to any deep and serious discussion of the foreign-aid story. The impact of locally- or regionally-purchased aid on developing economies can be significant. We have seen this most dramatically (and harmfully?) in Africa. Thanks for hitting on this.

Mark

Indicators are not perfect.

What is amusing though is that when the poverty indicator shows improvement, some folks pooh-pooh it as meaningless and not reflective of reality, yet if the same statistic shows a worsening of poverty, they'd be the last people to question it.

Stupid "Smart" People.

Right, because everything is a zero sum game. No country can create jobs without destroying jobs in other countries.

Tell me, which country did America steal all its jobs from in its rise from prominence over the past century and a half?

The high unemployment here is because of economic problems we, and specifically the housing and financial sectors, have created. If the financial crisis had not occurred, we would probably still be close to full employment, and even MORE people would have been lifted out of poverty in the developing world.
